title: World Geography: Recommended Grade Level: Grades 11 or 12
subject: Social Studies (2014-2020)

document.title: Indiana Department of Education College and Career Readiness

36D75B15B78F43A2B39F0E2832EBB254.description:
Create basic policies designed to guide the use and management of Earth’s resources and that reflect
multiple points of view.

FD09BA09F2154F7986EAD12705A0A627.description:
Identify examples from different world regions, involving the use and management of resources. Explain how
different points of view influence policies relating to the use of these resources.

4E2CB7BC4D444F28BA532CBFD30741EE.description:
Identify patterns of world resource distribution and utilization, and explain the consequences of the use of
renewable and nonrenewable resources.

B67B707ABEB34C6CB11441C5BD52E021.description:
Describe how and why the ability of people to use Earth’s resources to feed themselves has changed over
time

5F338AEAF93B40D0B4B111965CC336B6.description:
Analyze the possible effect of a natural disaster on the local community and devise plans to cope with a
disaster so as to minimize or mitigate its effects.

DC64D7F5FE8C450C8C2942A79366F369.description:
Map the occurrence and describe the effects of natural hazards throughout the world and explain ways to
cope with them.

4795D7366FB94FA68B974D61970003DB.description: Identify solutions to problems caused by environmental changes brought on by human activity

DB2FD5B5936E46ABA31B64A7F9987C80.description: Identify and describe the effect of human interaction on the world’s environment.

2F22121D83EE452A9F12FEC8EDB5918D.description:
Identify international political, economic, and social networks and organizations of global power and influence
 of places, countries, and regions, (Facebook, Doctors without Borders, the United Nations, the European
 Union, Association of Southeast Asian Nations/ASEAN) and report on the impact of each.

22DFFED72564431D9F6B90663D10627E.description:
Identify specific situations where human or cultural factors are involved in geographic conflict and identify
different viewpoints in the conflict. Create scenarios under which these cultural factors would no longer trigger
conflict.

4A3B981486594253B75216F9BC947B3C.description: Analyze the changing functions of cities over time.

A9E27EDF7DB943F3AA60A496523B9724.description: Explain how the internal structures of cities varies in different regions of the world and give examples.

6991C23CB7EF4C828453AC5E68DB555D.description: Describe and explain the worldwide trend toward urbanization and be able to graph the trend.

E0133C91EEED4607860137BBB5CF9124.description:
Use global political, economic, cultural, or social flows to describe and illustrate interdependence between
places, countries and regions.

B747642CEE644E63961DE746CDE030AB.description: Identify contemporary spatial patterns in the movement of goods and services throughout the world.

1515DDEF2E254306A4DEEE206770F92A.description:
Explain the meaning of the word infrastructure and analyze its relationship to a country’s level of
development.

5C478B4A0EB54FAE97DC805624790E5D.description:
Compare the levels of economic development of countries of the world in terms of Gross Domestic Product
per capita and key demographic and social indicators. Map and summarize the results.

681373B54D194DFDAD69101B8661562C.description:
Describe and locate on maps the worldwide occurrence of the three major economic systems – traditional,
planned and market – and describe the characteristics of each.

824024FFDF5F40418819CFD901DBEE01.description:
Identify patterns of economic activity in terms of primary (growing or extracting), secondary (manufacturing)
and tertiary (distributing and services) activities. Plot data and draw conclusions about how the percentage of
the working population in each of these categories varies by country and changes over time.

7F4549F622FD4ED9BF0BA51910DFA442.description:
Explain how changes in communication and transportation technology contribute to the spread of ideas and
to cultural convergence* and divergence.

BC31BC8B0D2A40A296066ADF50A3A77E.description:
Map the distribution pattern of the world’s major languages. Map and explain the concept of a lingua franca*
in various parts of the world. (History; Individuals, Society and Culture)

68FF2A29E65E4238BBF78EB9022427AD.description: Map the distribution patterns of the world’s major religions and identify cultural features associated with each.

A3F327E1221248D6863CBF270F8A3A75.description:
Assess the consequences of population growth or decline in various parts of the United States and determine
whether the local community is shrinking or growing.

8E55BD49741F4C799B3E1440EF02AECA.description:
Evaluate the impact of human migration on physical and human systems. (Economic; Government;
Individuals, Society and Culture)

CA3C14E9CED24519BF845AA1A7630B38.description:
Hypothesize about the impact of push factors and pull factors on human migration in selected regions and
about changes in these factors over time.

A08931C005E24A2299C21D07F87A5305.description:
Develop maps of human migration and settlement patterns at different times in history and compare them to
the present.

79DA3C76EC774E1D8C8E2DCB6C062141.description:
Using maps, establish world patterns of population distribution, density and growth. Relate population growth
rates to health statistics, food supply or measure of well-being. Explain that population patterns differ not only
among countries but also among regions within a single country.

88D6527198E9434F8D3E29B454115EE2.description:
Illustrate and graph with precision the occurrence of earthquakes on Earth over a given period of time (at
least several months) and draw conclusions concerning regions of tectonic instability.

B22962C69411430B81A1B06524F872B9.description:
Explain and give examples of the physical processes that shape Earth’s surface that result in existing
landforms and identify specific places where these processes occur.

24F34128072B4241953DE4D8150B160E.description: Describe the world patterns of natural vegetation and biodiversity and their relations to world climate patterns.

49D4E630A7424F5CB74B859B13383F25.description:
Identify and account for the distribution pattern of the world’s climates, taking into account the Earth/Sun
relationship, ocean currents, prevailing winds, and latitude and longitude.

F8E33EB15AD34A41A9DDD484845229FE.description:
Define Earth’s physical systems: atmosphere, lithosphere, biosphere or hydrosphere. Categorize the
elements of the natural environment as belonging to one of the four components.

0840521F90AC465F9BD1D79F352D5332.description:
Give examples of how people create regions to understand Earth’s complexity. (Individuals, Society and
Culture)

E8BB55AFF2574105A08077EBFF0FE294.description:
Explain how the concept of “region” is used as a way of categorizing, interpreting and ordering complex
information about Earth.

6FE3E55880DE4A218F821F21F34EB480.description:
Give examples and analyze ways in which people’s changing views of places and regions reflect cultural
 changes; understand how people’s views of physical features influence and are influenced by human
 behavior.

3F4D4CE3B83744ACABB98012416D5B43.description: Give examples of how and why places and regions change or do not change over time.

187925E0978A48C4ACE29FEF9219FF42.description:
Ask geographic questions and obtain answers from a variety of sources, such as books, atlases and other
 written materials; statistical source material; fieldwork and interviews; remote sensing; and GIS. Reach
 conclusions and give oral, written, graphic and cartographic expression to conclusions.

5393C06C2E0744598DB670491CA2CD71.description:
Evaluate the applications of geographic tools (locational technologies) and supporting technologies to serve
particular purposes.

865A5D3074FF46768B47EB967D495825.description:
Create and compare mental maps or personal perceptions of places. Explain how experiences and culture
influence these perceptions and identify ways in which mental maps influence decisions.

DCED60D030924650A05EA3D4B856420D.description: Evaluate the source of particular maps to determine possible biases contained in them.

56F42A14E103425DBC5E2734B90A01E1.description:
Use locational technology such as remote sensing, Global Positioning Systems (GPS) and Geographic
Information Systems (GIS), to establish spatial relationships.
